text: oh hi everyone must then eat Tano here
the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of this new Jason
Isbell and the 400 unit record weather
veins this is the latest full-length LP
of Alabama native guitarist singer
songwriter as well as actor Jason Isbell
and his band this is his ninth
full-length studio album overall his
sixth with the 400 unit group and if
you're unfamiliar with Jason's stuff he
has long been a fixture on the southern
rock and ALT country scene going all the
way back to his days in drive-by
truckers in the 2000s but he has since
gone on to have a pretty successful solo
career selling hundreds of thousands of
Records between him and his band his
latest here being among some of his
highest charting too now I've been aware
of the Man's music for a minute and yet
I have not spoken at length about any of
his records specifically most because I
haven't had a strong affinity for them
because up until this point I think I've
just been very Jason Isbell neutral
although I'm trying not to be because
when it comes to country music more
broadly Jason puts out some pretty good
stuff it's tasteful it's quality it's
respectable sometimes his songs carry a
thoughtful and Progressive message that
you don't often catch from white country
leaning singer-songwriters and yet it
doesn't seem to kneecap his success or
commercial potential so regardless of
how you feel about Jason's music I think
his presence on the current Day music
scene is a net positive but with that
being said musically speaking I think
some of his albums can come across kind
of cliche by Americana standards anyway
and while Jason has enough taste to be
pulling from some of the greats in this
Lane be that Springsteen be that Neil
Young he also kind of lives in their
respective Shadows a bit too plus his
tunes and performances don't necessarily
have the bite that theirs did when they
were at their creative Peaks years ago
regardless I do always try to give
Jason's new records a shot as long as I
don't almost miss the release date like
I did here but when I eventually tried
this one I was surprised that it really
kind of gripped me right out of the gate
with the song Death Wish a track about
caring for and loving someone who is in
the throes of suicidal ideation from the
forlorn chords to Jason's
heart-wrenching vocal performance and
lyrics about devotion and just being
concerned with this individual's
well-being this one just cut steep so of
course this song goes down some pretty
dark twists and turns but there's some
elements of Hope in the lyrics as well
that show up as it progresses along with
some cinematic strings percolating up
underneath everything so yeah really
strong and powerful start to the album
and I was pretty impressed with a number
of songs to follow there's king of
Oklahoma big Neil Young Vibes coming off
this one with a very Grand Country Rock
instrumental that is backed up buy a
super fiery guitar solo and the lyrics
on this one read like a man going
through the worst time in his life
romantically and financially the chorus
basks in the glory of how good things
used to be at one point but then puts a
final nail in the coffin saying nothing
makes me feel like much of nothing
anymore
absolutely devastating I wouldn't say
this record is all doom and gloom though
there is middle of the morning the warm
and shiny acoustic guitars on this track
are gorgeous Jason lays down some killer
vocal leads that sound like a rooster
calling out into the morning and the way
I read this track it feels very much
like healing emotionally from living a
quiet and fearful life that's loaded
with tension just this unending fear in
a dynamic be that romantic or platonic
how walking on eggshells endlessly just
kind of feels like torture and mustering
the ability and the power to just kind
of reject it or change things honestly
it's really emotionally intelligent
writing which I could also save for the
track save the world which is a very
intense take on school shootings living
in the moment when the news breaks and
having that tragic sort of thing affect
you and your family personally the
vocals on this track are passionate the
instrumental performance is hard-hitting
and Jason expounds upon these themes at
one point asking should we keep the kids
home from school should we teach them to
fight questions that no parent should
have to ask themselves and again we get
some very devastating writing on this
record as Jason says something changing
inside my head something's drowning out
the light essentially losing hope I'd
also like to highlight the most strict
back track on the record that's cast
iron skillet a tender acoustic cut where
Jason's weary voice delivers some dismal
but also hilarious recommendations don't
wash the cast iron skillet don't drink
and drive you'll spill it Bittersweet
isn't accurate enough to describe the
unique mixture of Fear And Regret and
Nostalgia this song brings to the table
overall the track reads like a difficult
Crossroad between the modern world and a
world that someone like Jason grew up in
a more traditional one and how
Lifestyles and perspectives often change
with new generations now there's more on
the record of course there is because
this thing is about an hour long but
many of the other cuts on this thing
don't contain performances or
instrumentals that really grab my
attention or maybe there's a bit of a
musical and narrative mismatch like on
if you insist which is a story all about
picking up someone at a bar not
necessarily in a sleazy way more in a
sad and lonely way to just kind of avoid
emotional isolation but the Speedy pace
of the shuffling beat on this cut along
with the Plucky Acoustics just kind of
suck whatever drama out of this
narrative we could be getting the whole
thing sounds more peppy than sad despite
the fact that the lyrics are kind of
heart crushing especially as Jason asks
if this person wants to experience a
love that will tear through their life
like a category five or makes reference
to his own mother going through her own
spells of loneliness there's also when
we were close which reflects upon a
friendship between two musicians and
while I love the descriptions of this
friendship and the character portrait of
this other person in the lyrics the
plotting B and accentuated riffs it just
does not make for I think the best
texture and flavor on this record it
just comes off kind of hokey and maybe
that's because the song itself is trying
to be very meta like hey here's a track
about our wild and out of control and
sort of doomed Rock and Roll Lifestyle
let's make sure the song about it it
sounds like it's rocking I think the
final tune on the record two really hit
for me was volunteer where is spelled
describes a tragic childhood with
fighting parents eventually losing those
parents ending up in foster care running
away finding a young love but then some
simultaneously kind of struggling every
day through life essentially the song
asks who signed me up for this why is
this my life why am I set to deal with
this day in and day out which I think
says a lot about the normalization of
human suffering in our society but from
here the rest of the record in my
opinion it just kind of grows colder and
colder like a hot bath that was much
more comfortable to sit in more than
half an hour ago it also doesn't help
that we get some of the longest tracks
on the very back end of this album and
hearing Jason and the band really drag
some of these cuts out into Jammy or
passages I'll say it's not really their
strong suit on this ain't it for example
you can barely hear Jason singing even
some of the backup vocals as well as the
guitars blare over the entire thing like
it's a really messy live recording and
the even longer closing track miles
despite the instrumental switch up and
the kind of huge build toward the end of
the cut just doesn't finish things off
as a grand or as ambitiously as I had
hoped because there's a lot of volume to
be had in the mix for sure but the
playing itself still comes across super
plain and measured and just flat but
yeah biggest issue with this album is
that there are plenty of tracks that
pale in comparison to others and the
whole thing started a lot stronger than
it finished both instrumentally and
lyrically with that being said I think
Jason did put some of his strongest
material yet on this project some fiery
cuts for sure even if the Neil and
Springsteen Vibes are very obvious this
thing is likely to be one of the better
Americana albums of the year if that's
your Vibe if that's your sound make sure
you check it out I'm feeling a light
seven on this myself transition have you
given this album a listen did you love
it did you hate it what would you rate
it you're the best or the best what
should I review next hit the like if you
like Please Subscribe and please don't
cry hit the Bell as well over here next
to my head is another video you can
check out hit that up or the link to
subscribe to the channel Anthony fantana
now Jason Isbell forever
